title: IELTS Listening Test 05
content: Complete IELTS Listening Test 5 with all 4 sections (40 questions)

questions.instructions:
Questions 1-5

Complete the form below.

Write NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER for each answer.
questions.question: Applicant Details Form
questions.no_answer_feedback: In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! You completed the form correctly.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Some answers are incorrect. Review the applicant details.

field_answers.5: weekends|weekend|on weekends|at weekends|at the weekend|on the weekends

5.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen to the availability restrictions.
5.no_answer: The correct answer is: WEEKENDS. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

Question 31

sections.transcript:
Section 1
Interviewer Hello, nice to meet you after talking on the phone. So you’re interested in signing up with our employment agency for some temporary work?
Candidate Yes [Q8: I] am. I am going overseas in about 6 months, but I am available for work until then.
Interviewer Okay, that’s great. Well, I’ll just write down some of your details as we talk. So what’s your full name, I know your first name is Sharon.
Candidate Yes, that’s correct Sharon (Q1) [Q1: Haltwell].
Interviewer Is that Altwell with an [Q9: A]?
Candidate No actually it beings with [Q7: H] – so its H-A-L-T-W-E-L-L
Interviewer Okay. And your address please?
Candidate It’s 24a Rodney Road. R-O-D-N-E-Y.
Interviewer And which area is it?
Candidate Sandwell. Do you need the postcode?
Interviewer Yes, please. If you know it.
Candidate Its SD7 (Q2) [Q2: 12PY]
Interviewer Alright, and I have your phone number here from when I returned your call the other day, 915 2334, isn’t it?
Candidate Yes
Interviewer Now are you looking to start work immediately, I mean, when is the first day you would be available for work?
Candidate Oh, not this week actually, as I already have some commitments. What’s today’s date… the 6th , okay so that means I would be free from the (Q3) 12th of [Q3: November].
Interviewer That’s no problem. Now you are looking for customer service work aren’t you?
Candidate Yes I am. That’s what I’ve been doing for the last few years.
Interviewer So how many years’ experience do you have in that area?
Candidate Let me think… 3. No, (Q4) [Q4: 4 years]' experience – it’s what I’ve done since I left college.
Interviewer And are you looking for full-time work?
Candidate Yes I am, but I would also consider part-time too, I mean if that was the only thing available.
Interviewer We have quite a few full-time positions actually, but most of them involve working shifts – you know evenings and [Q5: weekends] – would that fit your schedule?
Candidate Evenings are no problem, but I wouldn’t be able to work (Q5)weekends until after January 3rd – I already have a job at a department store you see and I am contracted until then, after that I’m completely flexible.
Interviewer Okay, I’ll just make a note of that.
Interviewer Now do you have your education certificates with you? We need to make copies and put them in your file?
Candidate Yes, I do they’re here.
Interviewer Okay thanks…. So you have completed high school and also have a Diploma in Administration?
Candidate Yes that’s right. It was a two year course and I studied at Calstone College
Interviewer Good. (Q6) Now here is how the process works. I am now going to ask you to complete a short computing skills test, it takes around 45 minutes. You know most customer service jobs involve having to have good keyboard skills. Do you have time for that today?
Candidate Yes, no problem - I can do that now.
Interviewer Good, so we will be able to give you your results immediately, as it is all computerised. If you pass, we will put your details into our database as an available employee from the dates you specified, but before we can activate your details on our database, (Q7) we need to check references. I have some details here, so is it okay if I telephone these people today?
Candidate Yes that’s fine
Interviewer Once we’ve done that, if all is okay, your details will be activated in the database and (Q8) one of our representatives will contact our client companies to see if any of them would be interested in taking you on.
Candidate That sounds fine.
Interviewer (Q9) We will telephone you to inform you of an assignment and would normally expect you to confirm whether you are willing to take on the position within 24 hours of the confirmation phone call.(Q10) We will then email you an employment contract which you must sign and return as soon as possible
Candidate That sounds fine.
Interviewer Okay, well let’s go and start the test.

Section 2 Good afternoon, and thank you very much for inviting me to the community hall for this brief presentation on music – or to be more specific, vinyl records and record players. Now, as I am sure many of you are aware, records have once again become very popular in many countries, and record sales are nearly at the point of overtaking CD sales – that figure is not the units sold, but the overall amount spent on this format. Of course, digital music from streaming services are still the major format most people use to listen to music, but the gap between digital music and records is closing. I’d like to start by talking about the history of records and recorded music. Some of you may be familiar with the name Thomas Edison. He is credited as having created the light bulb and other inventions, and is also recognised as the first person to have recorded music on to a disc.  These early music records were made from a range of materials, including hard rubber. However, there were some issues with the number of times a record could be played before it simply wore out, and the variable quality of manufacture meant that reproductions were not always very good copies of the original music. Over the years, styles of manufacture changed, as did the materials used. The first to replace the original rubber records used a substance known as shellac, mixed with wax and paper. It was found that this combination meant that the sound quality was better and the records themselves could be played many more times without a reduction in the sound quality. The public reaction to these new records was overwhelmingly positive, with sales increasing significantly in just a matter of months. Mass production of this new shellac record first began in 1898 in Hanover, Germany, and the same formula was used to create records for over 50 years. However, despite their popularity, there was a drawback – the records needed to be handled carefully, as the shellac that was used meant that the record could easily break if it was dropped or bent. There was actually an alternative which was advertised and sold as ‘unbreakable’, but these records, usually made of celluloid - an early form of plastic – suffered from an exceptionally high level of background noise and were never as popular. However, in the late 1940s, there were radical changes in the production process as vinyl records became the new music standard. Vinyl records did not shatter when dropped and were available in a range of different colours, a new development from records that had previously been only black or brown. These new vinyl records become wildly popular, but this is not to say that they did not have their drawbacks. They could be damaged by incorrect storage, heat or even exposure to sunlight, but nonetheless, by the 1950s and beyond, the number of people who had a record player and spent money on records increased dramatically.
Now I’m going to tell you a little about a common record player from around the 1970s. The example you can see here is actually from 1976, so has no digital displays or anything overly technical, although it was a very popular record player at the time. The largest section of a record player is the plate – here you can see that that’s the large, circular section on which the record sits. Normally you will see a slip mat on [Q16: the record plate], designed to hold the record in place. Right in the middle of the plate is the spindle, which keeps the record in the middle of the plate as it revolves. In the bottom left corner, you can see [Q17: the power light], which in this example has a slightly raised, circular shape. This light simply indicates whether the turntable is plugged in. Just beside the power light are three buttons, the largest of which is to start or stop the player. The two smaller buttons to the right control the speed at which the record will spin. In older record players like this, the buttons have numbers which indicate the speed at which the record will turn. This is measured in revolutions, or ‘spins’, per minute, referred to as RPMs. The first of these buttons – the one closest to the large button – is for playing [Q18: 33] RPM records and the other one is for [Q19: 45] RPM records. Now moving over to the other side, we can see the volume slider, which of course controls how loud the record will sound. On the same side at the back you will also see one of the of the most important piece of the record player. Starting right at the back corner, you can see a larger weight – this is the counterweight, and this can be moved to balance the whole arm. Now that arm, technically referred to as the [Q20: tone arm], ends with the cartridge. In a typical record player – even some of the more modern versions – this is the part that needs the most care and attention, and often needs to be replaced. The cartridge is where the needle is, and it is from this section (fade)

Section 3
Teacher Well, I would first of all like to congratulate everyone on going out and completing your interviews for our survey last week. I know it must have been difficult practicing your English in the [Q30: real] world and interviewing native speakers of English, who you have never met before, must have been a challenge. I hope you enjoyed the exercise and found some interesting information on lifestyles here in this country. I’d now like the leaders for each of the groups to give me some feedback. First, let’s hear from you John.
John Well…as English is not our first language I expected it would be quite difficult talking to people we had never met before. I was (Q21) [Q21: quite nervous] about having to go out and interview strangers; but once we started I enjoyed it and we met some very friendly and interesting people.
Teacher And how about your group Connie? What did you find to be most challenging about the exercise?
Connie Well, I think it was when we eventually went over to people to ask if they would take part in the survey, it was fine once we had started the conversation, but approaching people was quite nerve-wrecking as we could never be sure that they would be friendly and happy to help, or whether they would be (Q22) [Q22: rude] to us.
Teacher And so were many people rude to you?
Connie No they weren’t. Some people would not answer questions because they were on their lunch break from work and were in a hurry, everybody else was happy to help – and even the people who didn’t complete the survey because they didn’t have time were still friendly and polite. We found it particularly useful as we (Q23) [Q23: recorded] the interviews on audio tape, so we could listen again when we had finished. We realised afterwards that we had misunderstood quite few things people were saying at the time. it was interesting to find out about the different (Q24) [Q24: culture]
Teacher So John, how did your group decide who to interview?
John Well, our questions were asking about how frequently people took exercise and what sorts of hobbies and interests they pursued in their spare time. We decided that we should try to interview a variation of different age groups and an (Q25) [Q25: equal number] of men and women.
Teacher And how did you split them by age group?
John Two members of the team were told to interview teenagers – people who looked like they were 18 or under. Then two people focused on people who looked to be between 18-35. Two more were stopping people who seemed to be between the 35-50 age group and than I interviewed people who looked to be over 50.
Teacher And what was the topic for your survey Connie ?
Connie We asked our interviewees about attitudes to healthy eating - you know, whether they ate [Q29: junk food] such as burgers and fries or more wholesome food. We also asked them about how often they drank things like (Q26) coffee and [Q26: alcohol].
Teacher And how many interviews did your group complete John?
John We interviewed 18 people in total and had an additional 4 who would not stop to answer questions. Our original target was 20 so we did pretty well I think.
Teacher So Connie, how many people did your group talk to?
Connie We managed to complete all 20 interviews and three people were too busy to stop and help us.
Teacher Well, I think that’s very good, well done to both groups.
Teacher So, John, what did you group find out about exercise habits and hobbies?
John Well we found that the males who were under 35 were more likely to be a member of a sports team, such as cricket, soccer or rugby than either the older age groups or women. Women were more involved in (Q27) [Q27: individual exercise] such as yoga, aerobics or going to the gym, rather than being members of an actual team. Sailing was the most popular sport for the over 35s followed by hiking and then golf.
Teacher Okay, so that covers sports, what about other ways of relaxing and enjoying leisure time?
John As you’d expect, the under 18s were the more frequent users of the internet, but the most popular pastime in that category was socializing with friends. There were a wide variety of hobbies and interests mentioned in the other age groups including (Q28) [Q28: reading], attending sports games as a spectator, playing chess and craftwork.
Teacher That’s interesting. And Connie, what did your group discover about eating and drinking habits?
Connie It seemed that the older groups (those over 35) were more concerned about healthy eating. They ate (Q29) junk food less often than the 18-35s, on average once every two weeks as opposed to once or twice a week. All age categories said that they believed they ate enough fruit, interestingly, more 18-35s than people in older categories said they thought that they didn’t eat vegetables often enough.
Teacher And what about drinking habits?
Connie Drinking coffee was popular for all age categories and there was a trend towards preferring (Q30) real coffee as opposed to instant varieties. The 18-35s said that they would regularly buy coffee to take away from well known outlets. Most people said that they drank only safe amounts of alcohol and the most popular alcoholic drinks were wine and beer.
Teacher That’s great, once again well done. We will have our next class in the computer lab and we’ll look at ways of analysing information from market research surveys.

Section 4 Good morning everyone. Welcome to our third lecture in this series on contemporary concepts in science. Today we are going to examine some relatively new ideas which have entered the scientific lexicon. To begin with we’ll look at what has become known as the Goldilocks Effect or Principle. Most of you will be familiar with the fairy-tale of “Goldilocks and the Three Bears” where [Q39: a] little girl strays into the bears’ house and samples their food and furniture. She tests each of the bear’s porridge, chairs and beds to find the one that suits her best, the one that is “[Q31: just right]”. Well the concept of things being ‘just right’, of falling within certain optimal limits, neither too extreme nor too simple has been termed the Goldilocks effect  and it has crept into scientific language in a wide range of fields. One of the earlier uses of the term was by ecologists seeking to explain a number of different phenomena. In 2008, Eric Berlow and his colleagues entitled a paper, The “Goldilocks factor” in food webs. In this work they use the concept to explain how stable food chains in natural environments come into being, in other words what determines who eats who. It was found that body size is strongly linked to this question, so that predators eat creatures which are smaller than them but not too small. Thus a shark would eat a seal but probably not bother with shrimp.  Another group led by Gabrielle Katz used the expression to explain why streams in Arizona which had variable water flows supported more species of plant life than those that were consistently wet or dry. Earth scientists have also been employing the phrase to describe the conditions that create a liveable planet. It has been theorised that the Earth hasn’t become an unendurably hot planet like Venus, nor a freezing cold one like Mars is partially due to the role of the greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide, in the geological cycle. It has been known for some time that CO2 is absorbed by mountain ranges and other large land masses and that volcanoes emit CO2. More recently it has been discovered that new rock which is pushed up in the process of geological upheaval releases a large amount of CO2 also. Due to the Earth’s self-regulating cycle, it has been dubbed the Goldilocks planet. This has received some condemnation for ignoring the facts of current climate change, and by making it seem we can continue to pump out greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. Astrobiologists have extended the concept into their search for other inhabitable planets, and other intelligent life forms. Planets that would qualify as Goldilocks planets would be not too big nor too small, they’[Q36: d] be the right distance from their star for life to exist and they’d have water. That is, they would be “just right” to sustain life.  It should be noted though that some planets which fall into this category could also be ‘gas giants’ like Jupiter and would be uninhabitable due to their toxic gassy environments. NASA’s Kepler space observatory has the task of exploring our galaxy in order to discover other Goldilocks planets. Possibly 40 billion such planets could exist according to estimations based on the data received from Kepler. Recently psychologists at the University of Rochester have applied the term to observations of very young children’s attention behaviour. By measuring the eye movements of a group of 7 and 8 month old babies watching video animations of increasing complexity the researchers were able to gauge when the infants would stop watching a video.  The children would lose interest if the video was too simple, or too complex or surprising. Thus videos that captured the children’s attention were ‘just right’, the right mixture of novelty ( not boring or frightening) and challenge (not too familiar or too confusing). Steven Piantoadosi, one of the researchers, states that their findings have wider implications for other types of learning, where the ideal materials for learning should be ‘just right’, stimulating but not too difficult. Now whether the Goldilocks principle is truly a scientific law, or a description of a certain state or just a buzz word is still open to debate. However, it is becoming an increasing popular expression. Medical science has adopted it to refer to the optimal dose of a medication. Economics has jumped on the bandwagon with Goldilocks economies, Goldilocks markets, Goldilocks pricing and Goldilocks marketing, all of which set out the perfect factors for economic wellbeing. It has been used in TED talks by cultural commentators to describe the best balance of independence and closeness in personal relationships. Goldilocks theory is becoming ubiquitous, just google it, but for all that it may merely be post-hoc theorising. That is, tailoring a theory after the fact, where things are explained in a way that can’t be tested, particularly in the field of human behaviour. Using such a theory a researcher could interpret observed patterns of behaviour as they choose, and state that the desired behavioural outcome is the result of a perfect balance of conditions. Or as one commentator has put it, when you see Goldilocks, look out. Now, I want to look at the Higgs Boson, the so-called god particle…
